paragraph.content: the way and form in which the information or document is to be provided.

subsection.leadIn: The power under subsection (2) to require a person to provide information or a document includes—

paragraph.name: a

subparagraph.content: in a visible and legible form; or
in a form from which it can readily be produced in a visible and legible form; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: if the information or document is stored electronically, the power to require—

subparagraph.content: the provision of directions on the operation of the equipment containing the information or document; and
the provision of the appropriate system for reducing the information or document into a written form on paper.

subsection.leadIn: The power under subsection (2) to require a person to provide a document includes—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: if the document is provided, the power—

subparagraph.content: to make copies of it or to take extracts from it; or
to require the person, or another person whom the investigator reasonably believes is able to do so, to give an explanation of, or further particulars about, the document; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the document is not provided, the power to require the person to state, to the best of the person’s knowledge and belief, where it is.

section.name: s74
section.heading: Power to enter and search, etc.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of conducting an investigation under section 71, an investigator may, at any reasonable time—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: stop, board and search any vehicle or vessel that the investigator reasonably suspects to be arranged for transporting a tour group;

paragraph.name: c
d
paragraph.content: require any person whom the investigator reasonably suspects to be working as a tourist guide or tour escort to produce the person’s licence and identity card for inspection; and

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: make any examination and inquiry that the investigator considers necessary for the purposes of the investigation.

subsection.content: An investigator authorized by a warrant issued under section 75 to enter and search any premises may take with the investigator any other person and any equipment that the investigator reasonably considers necessary in entering and searching the premises.

section.name: s75
section.heading: Warrant to enter and search, etc.

subsection.content: A magistrate may issue a warrant to an investigator in respect of any premises if the magistrate is satisfied by information on oath that there is reasonable ground for suspecting that there are at the premises documents or things that are or contain evidence for the purposes of an investigation conducted under section 71.

subsection.leadIn: A warrant issued under subsection (1) to an investigator in respect of any premises authorizes the investigator to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: enter and search the premises; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: seize, remove and detain any document or thing at the premises that the investigator reasonably suspects to be or to contain evidence for the purposes of an investigation conducted under section 71.

subsection.leadIn: If property is produced to an investigator in response to a requirement under this Part or is obtained under a warrant issued under section 75, the investigator may retain that property—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for as long as may be necessary for the purposes of the investigation; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where it may be required for legal proceedings, for as long as may be necessary for the purposes of the proceedings.

subsection.content: If a document (including a document in electronic form) obtained under this Part is in the possession of the investigator, the investigator must, if requested by a person otherwise entitled to possession of the document, provide that person with a copy of the document certified by the Authority to be a true copy of the original (certified copy).

Until such a certified copy is provided, the investigator must, at the time and place the investigator reasonably considers appropriate, permit a person otherwise entitled to possession of the document, or a person authorized by that person, to inspect and make copies of, or take extracts from, the document.
A certified copy of a document provided under this section is admissible in evidence in all courts as if it were the original.
If any property has come into the possession of the investigator under this Ordinance, a magistrate may order the disposal of the property in the way provided in this section.

subsection.leadIn: The magistrate may, whether on the magistrate’s own initiative or on application by the Authority or an interested person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: make an order for the delivery of the property to the person who appears to the magistrate to be entitled to the property;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the person entitled to the property is unknown or cannot be found, make an order that the property be sold or retained in the possession of the magistrate or the Authority; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if the property is of no value, make an order that the property be destroyed.

subsection.leadIn: An order for the delivery, sale or destruction of property must not, except if the property is perishable, be made under subsection (2) unless the magistrate is satisfied that the property will not be required for the purpose of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any proceedings before the magistrate or any other court; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any proceedings under Part 7 or 8.

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the magistrate orders the sale or retention of any property under subsection (2)(b); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: no person establishes a claim to the property or the proceeds of sale of the property within 6 months after the date on which the order is made,

subsection.continued: the magistrate may, whether on the magistrate’s own initiative or on application by the Authority, order that the property or the proceeds of sale become the property of the Government.

subsection.content: An order made under subsection (2), other than an order for the retention of property, must not, except if the property is perishable, be carried out until the period for making an appeal against the order has expired or, if such an appeal is made, until the appeal is disposed of.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (5), an appeal is disposed of if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: it is determined and the period for bringing any further appeal has ended; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it is abandoned or otherwise ceases to have effect.

subsection.leadIn: This section applies if, in relation to an investigation conducted under section 71, an investigator reasonably believes that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person is likely to be able to assist the investigator in relation to the investigation by producing any information or document or giving any evidence that the investigator may require; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person intends to leave Hong Kong, or has left Hong Kong to reside elsewhere.

subsection.content: The investigator may apply to a magistrate for an order prohibiting the person from leaving Hong Kong without first assisting the investigator in relation to the investigation.

subsection.leadIn: If the magistrate is satisfied that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the investigator’s application is well-founded; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it is in the public interest to ensure that the person does not leave Hong Kong, or if the person having left, and returned to, Hong Kong, does not leave again, without first assisting the investigator in relation to the investigation,

subsection.continued: the magistrate may make an order against the person and issue the order to the Director of Immigration and the Commissioner of Police, directing them to prevent the person from leaving Hong Kong without first assisting the investigator in relation to the investigation.

subsection.content: The magistrate must, as soon as practicable after the prohibition order is made, serve a copy of it on the subject person, if the person can be found.

subsection.leadIn: Whether or not a copy of the prohibition order is served, the order—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: comes into force immediately after it is made; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: continues in force until—

subparagraph.content: the subject person has given assistance to the satisfaction of the investigator in relation to the investigation; or
the order is set aside under section 80(2)(a)(i).

subsection.leadIn: An enforcement officer may take any steps (including the use of force) that may be necessary to prevent the subject person from leaving Hong Kong if the officer reasonably believes that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the prohibition order against the person is in force;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person is about to leave Hong Kong; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: the person has not been permitted to leave Hong Kong under—

subparagraph.content: an authorization given by the Authority under section 79(1); or
an order made by the Court of First Instance under section 80(2)(a).

subsection.leadIn: The investigator must, as soon as practicable after—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the subject person has given assistance to the satisfaction of the investigator in relation to the investigation;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Authority has authorized the subject person to leave Hong Kong under section 79(1); or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the prohibition order has been set aside or suspended under section 80(2)(a),

subsection.continued: notify the Director of Immigration and the Commissioner of Police that the subject person is permitted to leave Hong Kong.

section.name: s79
section.heading: Change to prohibition order by Authority

subsection.content: The Authority may, for good cause, whether on its own initiative or on application by a subject person, authorize the person to leave Hong Kong on one or more occasions as specified in the authorization.

subsection.leadIn: The Authority must, by notice in writing given to the subject person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the Authority decides to give the authorization, notify the person of the decision; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: if, on the application by the person, the Authority decides not to give the authorization—

subparagraph.content: notify the person of the decision; and
give reasons for the decision.

section.name: s80
section.heading: Change to prohibition order by Court

subsection.content: If a subject person is aggrieved by a prohibition order or a decision under section 79(2)(b), the person may appeal to the Court of First Instance against the order or decision.

subsection.leadIn: The Court of First Instance may order that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the prohibition order be—

subparagraph.content: set aside; or
suspended or otherwise varied; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the appeal be dismissed.

subsection.content: On making an order under subsection (2)(a), the Court of First Instance may impose any conditions it considers appropriate.

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if the person, without reasonable excuse—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: obstructs an inspector in the performance of the inspector’s functions under section 69; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: fails to give any assistance, or provide any information or document, that an inspector reasonably requires in the performance of the inspector’s functions under section 69.

subsection.content: A person who commits an offence under this section is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months.
A person commits an offence if the person, without reasonable excuse, fails to comply with a requirement of a notice given to the person under section 73(2).

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person, in purported compliance with a requirement of a notice given to the person under section 73(2), provides any information or document, gives any answer, explanation or particular, or makes any statement, that is false or misleading in a material particular; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person knows that, or is reckless as to whether, the information, document, answer, explanation, particular or statement is false or misleading in a material particular.

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if the person, without reasonable excuse—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: obstructs an investigator in the performance of the investigator’s functions under section 74; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: fails to give any assistance, or provide any information or document, that an investigator reasonably requires in the performance of the investigator’s functions under section 74.

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under subsection (1) or (2) is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.content: A person who commits an offence under subsection (3) is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a copy of a prohibition order has been served on the person or the person has been verbally advised of its existence by an enforcement officer;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the person has not been permitted to leave Hong Kong under—

subparagraph.content: an authorization given by the Authority under section 79(1); or
an order made by the Court of First Instance under section 80(2)(a); and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the person leaves or attempts to leave Hong Kong.

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under this section is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.content: A person who, in connection with an inspection under Division 2, or an investigation under Division 3, gives evidence to the Authority has the same privileges and immunities as the person would have if the inspection or investigation were a proceeding in a court.
In subsection (1), the reference to the giving of evidence includes a reference to providing any information or document, giving any answer, explanation or particular, and making any statement.

section.name: s85
section.heading: Interpretation of Part 7
section.leadIn: In this Part—
section.def: licensee (持牌人) includes a person who was the holder of a licence.

subsection.content: The Authority must establish a disciplinary committee.

subsection.leadIn: The disciplinary committee is to consist of the following members—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the chairperson;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: 2 vice-chairpersons;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: at least 15 ordinary members.

subsection.content: Each member of the disciplinary committee is to be appointed by the Authority.

subsection.leadIn: In appointing the members of the disciplinary committee, the Authority must ensure that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the chairperson and vice-chairpersons are members of the Authority who are non-trade members;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: at least 8 of the ordinary members are members of the Authority, of whom at least half are non-trade members; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: for the ordinary members who are not members of the Authority, at least half of them are non-trade members.

subsection.content: Each member of the disciplinary committee is to be appointed for a period of not more than 2 years, but is eligible for reappointment.

section.name: s87
section.heading: Resignation of members of disciplinary committee

subsection.content: A member of the disciplinary committee may, at any time, resign from office by giving written notice of the resignation to the Chairperson.
The notice must be signed by the member.

subsection.leadIn: The notice takes effect on—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the date on which the notice is received by the Chairperson; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if a later date is specified in the notice, the later date.

section.name: s88
section.heading: Removal of members of disciplinary committee from office

subsection.content: The Authority may remove a member of the disciplinary committee from office if the Authority considers that the removal is desirable for the committee to effectively perform its functions.
If a member of the disciplinary committee is removed from office, the Authority must give the member written notice informing the member of the removal.

section.name: s89
section.heading: Authority may give directions to disciplinary committee

subsection.content: The Authority may give written directions to the disciplinary committee, whether generally or in any particular case, and whether regarding the way in which it must act or otherwise.
The disciplinary committee must act in accordance with the directions.

section.name: s90
section.heading: Disciplinary committee may give general directions

subsection.leadIn: The disciplinary committee may give general written directions on matters relating to the performance of functions by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the chairperson of the committee;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any person exercising the functions of the chairperson of the committee under section 97 or 98; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: an inquiry committee.

subsection.content: The chairperson of the disciplinary committee, the person referred to in subsection (1)(b) and an inquiry committee must act in accordance with the directions.

section.name: s91
section.heading: General procedure for meeting of disciplinary committee

subsection.content: Subject to this Division and the regulations made under section 163, the procedure for convening meetings of the disciplinary committee and for the conduct of business at those meetings is to be decided by the committee.

subsection.leadIn: A meeting of the disciplinary committee is to be presided over by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the chairperson of the committee; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the chairperson of the committee is absent, one of the vice-chairpersons.

subsection.content: The quorum for a meeting of the disciplinary committee is one half of the members of the committee.
For determining the quorum, if the number of members of the disciplinary committee is not an even number, the number is to be regarded as having been increased by 1.
At a meeting of the disciplinary committee, every question before the committee is to be decided by a majority of votes of the members present and entitled to vote.
Subject to subsection (3), each member of the disciplinary committee who is present at the meeting has 1 vote.
If there is an equality of votes in respect of any question to be decided at the meeting, the member who is presiding over the meeting has a casting vote in addition to his or her original vote.

section.name: s94
section.heading: Minutes
section.content: The disciplinary committee must maintain minutes of the proceedings, including a record of all decisions made, at each meeting of the committee.

section.name: s95
section.heading: Disclosure of interests in matters under discussion

subsection.leadIn: If a member of the disciplinary committee has a disclosable interest in a matter under discussion at a meeting of the committee—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the member must disclose the nature of the interest at the meeting; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the disclosure must be recorded in the minutes.

subsection.leadIn: If the member making the disclosure is not presiding over the meeting, the person who is presiding over the meeting may make any of the following directions—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the member must withdraw from the meeting during the discussion;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the member must not vote in relation to the matter under discussion;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the member must not be counted for a quorum.

subsection.leadIn: If the member making the disclosure is presiding over the meeting—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the member must not continue to preside over the meeting during the discussion; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the majority of the other members present may make any of the following directions—

subparagraph.content: the member must withdraw from the meeting during the discussion;
the member must not vote in relation to the matter under discussion;
the member must not be counted for a quorum.

subsection.content: The validity of any proceedings of the disciplinary committee is not affected by the failure by a member of the committee to comply with this section.

section.name: s96
section.heading: Authority to refer facts of case to chairperson of disciplinary committee

subsection.content: At the conclusion of an investigation conducted because of a case of complaint lodged under section 70, or a case of suspicion mentioned in section 71(b), in relation to a licensee, the Authority may refer the facts of the case to the chairperson of the disciplinary committee.
The chairperson of the disciplinary committee must consider the facts of the case.

subsection.leadIn: If the chairperson of the disciplinary committee has a disclosable interest in the case—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the chairperson must disclose the nature of the interest to the Chairperson;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the chairperson must not deal with the case; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: the Authority may appoint another member of the committee who—

subparagraph.content: is a non-trade member; and
does not have a disclosable interest in the case,

paragraph.continued: to deal with the case and, for this purpose, the references to the chairperson in sections 97 and 98 are construed to be references to that member.

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (3), the chairperson of the disciplinary committee may delegate the chairperson’s functions under sections 97 and 98 to a vice-chairperson of the committee who does not have a disclosable interest in the case.

section.name: s97
section.heading: Chairperson of disciplinary committee may decide case not to proceed

subsection.content: This section applies to a case investigated under section 71(a), the facts of which have been referred to the chairperson of the disciplinary committee.

If the chairperson of the disciplinary committee is satisfied that the case is trivial, frivolous, vexatious, misconceived or lacking in substance, the chairperson may decide that the case is not to proceed further.

subsection.leadIn: If the chairperson of the disciplinary committee decides that the case is not to proceed further, the chairperson must, by notice in writing given to the complainant concerned within 14 days beginning on the date on which the decision is made—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: notify the complainant of the decision; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: give reasons for the decision.

section.name: s98
section.heading: Chairperson of disciplinary committee may decide how case to proceed

subsection.content: This section applies to a case investigated under section 71(a) or (b), the facts of which have been referred to the chairperson of the disciplinary committee.

subsection.leadIn: If the chairperson of the disciplinary committee is satisfied that there is evidence that tends to establish the case—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: subject to paragraphs (b) and (c), the chairperson must establish an inquiry committee to conduct an inquiry into the case;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the chairperson may deal with the case in an expedited way in accordance with the regulations made under section 163 and make any of the orders described in section 107(1)(a), (b), (c), (d) and (e) against the licensee if the chairperson is satisfied that the licensee’s contravention of a requirement in this Ordinance is minor in nature; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the chairperson may recommend that the Authority revoke or suspend the licensee’s licence in a summary way under section 111 if the chairperson is satisfied of any of the matters set out in subsection (3).

subsection.leadIn: For subsection (2)(c), the matters are that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the licensee is not suitable to hold the licensee’s licence;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it is contrary to the public interest to permit the licensee to continue to hold the licensee’s licence;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: the act or conduct of the licensee—

subparagraph.content: endangers, or poses an imminent danger to, the safety of any person or property; or
brings, or poses an imminent risk of bringing, the travel industry of Hong Kong into disrepute.

subsection.content: The chairperson of the disciplinary committee must, as soon as practicable after a decision is made under subsection (2)(a) to conduct an inquiry in relation to a licensee, notify the licensee in writing of the decision.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of considering an order under subsection (2)(b) against a licensee—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the chairperson of the disciplinary committee may have regard to any record of conviction of the licensee; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: if the licensee was the holder of—

subparagraph.content: a previous licence;
a tourist guide pass; or
a tour escort pass,

paragraph.continued: the chairperson may also have regard to any disciplinary order that had been made by the Travel Industry Council against the licensee.

subsection.leadIn: When considering a record of conviction of a licensee under subsection (5)(a)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the chairperson of the disciplinary committee is not required to inquire into whether the licensee was properly convicted; but

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the chairperson may consider any record of the case in which the conviction was recorded and any other evidence that may be available and is relevant as showing the nature and gravity of the offence, including any mitigating or aggravating circumstances.

subsection.leadIn: If the chairperson of the disciplinary committee makes an order under subsection (2)(b) against a licensee, the chairperson must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: by notice in writing given to the licensee within 21 days beginning on the date on which the order is made—

subparagraph.content: notify the licensee of the order; and
give reasons for the order; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: publish notice of the order in any way the chairperson considers appropriate.

subsection.leadIn: An order made under subsection (2)(b) takes effect on—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the date of the notice given under subsection (7)(a); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if a later date is specified in the notice, the later date.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (8) applies even if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an appeal has been lodged under section 120(1)(h) against the order;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the period specified in section 120(2) has not expired; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a notice of the order has not been published under subsection (7)(b).

subsection.leadIn: An inquiry committee is to consist of the following members—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the chairperson;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: at least 2 ordinary members.

subsection.content: Only a member of the disciplinary committee is eligible to be a member of an inquiry committee.

subsection.leadIn: If an inquiry committee is established by the chairperson of the disciplinary committee—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the chairperson of the disciplinary committee; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a vice-chairperson of the disciplinary committee nominated by the chairperson of the disciplinary committee,

subsection.continued: is to be the chairperson of the inquiry committee.

subsection.leadIn: If an inquiry committee is not established by the chairperson of the disciplinary committee—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person who establishes the inquiry committee; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a vice-chairperson of the disciplinary committee nominated by the person who establishes the inquiry committee,

subsection.continued: is to be the chairperson of the inquiry committee.

subsection.content: In nominating a vice-chairperson of the disciplinary committee (nominee) as the chairperson of an inquiry committee under subsection (3)(b) or (4)(b), the person who establishes the inquiry committee must ensure that the nominee does not have a disclosable interest in the case into which an inquiry is to be conducted.
The ordinary members of an inquiry committee are to be appointed by the person who establishes the committee.

subsection.leadIn: In appointing the ordinary members of an inquiry committee, the person who establishes the committee must ensure that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: at least one of them is a trade member, and at least half of them are non-trade members; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: they do not have a disclosable interest in the case into which an inquiry is to be conducted.

section.name: s100
section.heading: General procedure for meeting of inquiry committee

subsection.content: Subject to this Division and the regulations made under section 163, the procedure for convening meetings of an inquiry committee and for the conduct of business at those meetings is to be decided by the committee.
A meeting of an inquiry committee is to be presided over by the chairperson of the committee.
The quorum for a meeting of an inquiry committee is 3 members of the committee or one half of the members of the committee, whichever is the greater.
For determining the quorum, if the number of members of an inquiry committee is not an even number, the number is to be regarded as having been increased by 1.
A meeting of an inquiry committee may be conducted only if a majority of the members present are non-trade members.
At a meeting of an inquiry committee, every question before the committee is to be decided by a majority of votes of the members present and entitled to vote.
Subject to subsection (3), each member of an inquiry committee who is present at the meeting has 1 vote.
If there is an equality of votes in respect of any question to be decided at the meeting, the chairperson of the inquiry committee has a casting vote in addition to his or her original vote.

section.name: s103
section.heading: Parties to inquiry
section.content: The parties to an inquiry are the licensee concerned, the Authority and the complainant (if any).

subsection.leadIn: An inquiry committee has the following powers when conducting an inquiry—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: power to take evidence on oath;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: power to summon a person to—

subparagraph.content: attend the inquiry as a witness;
give evidence; and
provide any information or document in the person’s possession or under the person’s control that may be relevant to the inquiry;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: power to examine witnesses;

paragraph.name: d
e
paragraph.content: power to determine the way in which any material mentioned in paragraph (d) is received;

paragraph.name: f
g
h
paragraph.content: power to make any order that may be necessary for or ancillary to the conduct of the inquiry or the carrying out of its functions.

subsection.content: With the consent of the licensee and the complainant (if any), the inquiry committee may conduct the inquiry on the basis of written submissions only.
After consulting the licensee and the complainant (if any), the inquiry committee may, on application by any of the parties to the inquiry, by order, give directions on who may be present.
For the purposes of subsection (3), the inquiry committee must have regard to the views or private interests of the licensee and of the complainant (if any), including any claims as to privilege.

subsection.leadIn: A party to the inquiry—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may, subject to any order made by the inquiry committee, be present at the inquiry; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: may participate—

subparagraph.content: in person;
through a legal representative; or
with the consent of the inquiry committee, through another person.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (5)(b)(i)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a company is to be regarded as participating in person if it participates through any of its directors; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a partnership is to be regarded as participating in person if it participates through any of its partners.

section.name: s105
section.heading: Summons
section.leadIn: A summons issued to a person under section 104(1)(b) must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: be in the specified form;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: be signed by the chairperson of the inquiry committee; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: specify the requirements that the person must comply with.

section.name: s106
section.heading: Prohibition on disclosure of inquiry matters

subsection.leadIn: An inquiry committee may, by order, prohibit or restrict the publication or disclosure by all or any of the persons present at the inquiry of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any evidence given at the inquiry; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any matter contained in any information or document provided or received in evidence at the inquiry.

subsection.content: If a person fails to comply with an order made under subsection (1), the inquiry committee may make an order against the person imposing a financial penalty not exceeding $5,000.

subsection.leadIn: If the inquiry committee makes an order under subsection (2) against a person, it must, by notice in writing given to the person within 21 days beginning on the date on which the order is made—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: notify the person of the order; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: give reasons for the order.

subsection.leadIn: An order made under subsection (2) takes effect on—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the date of the notice given under subsection (3); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if a later date is specified in the notice, the later date.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (4) applies even if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an appeal has been lodged under section 120(1)(i) against the order; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the period specified in section 120(2) has not expired.

subsection.leadIn: If, at the conclusion of an inquiry under section 104, an inquiry committee is satisfied that a matter mentioned in section 71(b)(i), (ii) or (iii) is established in respect of a licensee, the committee may make any of the following orders against the licensee—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an order giving a warning or reprimand;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an order imposing demerit points;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if the licensee is a licensed travel agent, an order imposing a financial penalty not exceeding $300,000;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: an order imposing a condition on the licensee’s licence;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: an order amending a condition of the licensee’s licence;

paragraph.name: f
g
paragraph.content: an order suspending the licensee’s licence or business permit for a specified period;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: an order revoking the licensee’s licence or business permit.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of considering an order under subsection (1) against a licensee—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the inquiry committee may have regard to any record of conviction of the licensee; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: if the licensee was the holder of—

subparagraph.content: a previous licence;
a tourist guide pass; or
a tour escort pass,

paragraph.continued: the inquiry committee may also have regard to any disciplinary order that had been made by the Travel Industry Council against the licensee.

subsection.leadIn: When considering a record of conviction of a licensee under subsection (2)(a)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the inquiry committee is not required to inquire into whether the licensee was properly convicted; but

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the inquiry committee may consider any record of the case in which the conviction was recorded and any other evidence that may be available and is relevant as showing the nature and gravity of the offence, including any mitigating or aggravating circumstances.

subsection.content: Before the inquiry committee makes an order under subsection (1) against a licensee, it must give the licensee a reasonable opportunity of being heard.

If the inquiry committee makes an order under subsection (1) against a licensee, it may also order the licensee to pay the costs and expenses incurred in relation to the inquiry, whether by the committee, any party to the inquiry, or any person attending the inquiry as a witness.

subsection.leadIn: If the inquiry committee makes an order under this section against a licensee, it must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: by notice in writing given to the licensee within 21 days beginning on the date on which the order is made—

subparagraph.content: notify the licensee of the order; and
give reasons for the order; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: publish notice of the order in any way the committee considers appropriate.

subsection.leadIn: An order made under this section takes effect on—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the date of the notice given under subsection (6)(a); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if a later date is specified in the notice, the later date.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (7) applies even if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an appeal has been lodged under section 120(1)(h) against the order;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the period specified in section 120(2) has not expired; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a notice of the order has not been published under subsection (6)(b).

subsection.content: A person commits an offence if the person, without reasonable excuse, fails to comply with a summons issued to the person under section 104(1)(b).

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person, in connection with an inquiry under section 104, gives any evidence, or provides any information or document, that is false or misleading in a material particular; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person knows that, or is reckless as to whether, the evidence, information or document is false or misleading in a material particular.

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under this section is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

section.name: s109
section.heading: Notices relating to order about authorized representative

subsection.content: This section applies if an inquiry committee makes an order requiring the authorized representative of a licensed travel agent to cease to be the travel agent’s authorized representative.

subsection.leadIn: The inquiry committee must, in the notice given to the travel agent under section 107(6)(a), notify the travel agent that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the travel agent must, within 14 days after the date of the notice, or a longer period the Authority may permit, apply to the Authority for approval of another individual as the travel agent’s authorized representative; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the travel agent fails to make the application within that period, or if the application is refused, the travel agent’s licence may be revoked or suspended.

subsection.leadIn: The inquiry committee must, within 21 days beginning on the date on which the order is made, by notice in writing given to an individual who is the travel agent’s authorized representative—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: notify the individual of the order;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: give reasons for the order; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: notify the individual that—

subparagraph.content: unless the ground for making the order no longer exists, an application for a travel agent licence, or the renewal of a travel agent licence, made during the specified period will be refused if the individual is proposed to be the applicant’s authorized representative.

subsection.content: The period specified under subsection (3)(c)(i) must be reasonable in the circumstances.

The travel agent must, within 14 days after the date of the notice given to the travel agent under section 107(6)(a), or a longer period the Authority may permit, apply to the Authority for approval of an individual as the travel agent’s authorized representative.

section.name: s110
section.heading: Application for approval of new authorized representative

subsection.leadIn: A licensed travel agent, in making an application under section 109(5), must give notice in writing to the Authority, setting out—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the particulars of the individual who is proposed to be the travel agent’s authorized representative (proposed individual); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the proposed individual’s consent.

subsection.content: On receiving a notice given under subsection (1), the Authority must decide whether, having regard to the matters set out in section 25(1), the proposed individual is suitable to be an authorized representative of a travel agent.

subsection.leadIn: If the Authority decides that the proposed individual is suitable, it may approve the application and may do one or more of the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: amend or remove the existing conditions of the travel agent licence;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: impose new conditions on the travel agent licence.

subsection.content: If the Authority decides that the proposed individual is not suitable, it may refuse the application.

subsection.leadIn: If the Authority intends to refuse the application, it must, by notice in writing given to the travel agent and proposed individual—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: notify the travel agent and individual of the intention; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: give reasons for the intention.

subsection.content: The travel agent and proposed individual may, within 7 days after the date of the notice given under subsection (5), or a longer period the Authority may permit, make representations in writing to the Authority as to why the Authority should not refuse the application.

subsection.leadIn: If the Authority decides to refuse the application, it must, within 21 days beginning on the date on which the decision is made—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: by notice in writing given to the travel agent—

subparagraph.content: notify the travel agent of the decision; and
give reasons for the decision; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: by notice in writing given to the proposed individual—

subparagraph.content: notify the individual of the decision;
give reasons for the decision; and

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: the individual will also not be suitable to be an authorized representative of any travel agent for the period specified in the notice; and

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: unless the ground for making the decision no longer exists, an application for a travel agent licence, or the renewal of a travel agent licence, made during the specified period will be refused if the individual is proposed to be the applicant’s authorized representative.

subsection.content: The period specified under subsection (7)(b)(iii)(A) must be reasonable in the circumstances.

division.name: D4
division.heading: Summary Procedure of Revocation or Suspension of Licence

section.name: s111
section.heading: Authority may revoke or suspend licence in summary way

subsection.leadIn: The Authority may revoke or suspend a licensee’s licence in a summary way if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the licensee receives a notice under section 28(4)(b) and—

subparagraph.content: the licensee fails to make an application under section 28(6) within the period specified in that section; or
the licensee makes the application, but the application is refused;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the authorized representative of the licensee dies or is incapable of acting and—

subparagraph.content: the licensee fails to make an application under section 29 within the period specified in that section; or
the licensee makes the application, but the application is refused;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the Authority receives a recommendation made by the chairperson of the disciplinary committee under section 98(2)(c); or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: section 109 applies and—

subparagraph.content: the licensee fails to make an application under section 109(5) within the period specified in that section; or
the licensee makes the application, but the application is refused.

subsection.leadIn: If the Authority decides to revoke or suspend a licensee’s licence in a summary way under subsection (1), it must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: by notice in writing given to the licensee within 21 days beginning on the date on which the decision is made—

subparagraph.content: notify the licensee of the decision; and
give reasons for the decision; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: publish notice of the decision in any way the Authority considers appropriate.

subsection.leadIn: A decision made under subsection (2) takes effect on—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the date of the notice given under subsection (2)(a); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if a later date is specified in the notice, the later date.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (3) applies even if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an appeal has been lodged under section 120(1)(d) against the decision;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the period specified in section 120(2) has not expired; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a notice of the decision has not been published under subsection (2)(b).

section.name: s112
section.heading: Authority’s additional power to revoke or suspend licence in summary way

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting section 111, the Authority may also revoke or suspend a licensee’s licence in a summary way if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the licensee fails to pay—

subparagraph.content: a registration fee required by section 32;
a financial penalty imposed under section 98(2)(b) or 107(1)(c); or
a levy required by section 146 or 147; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for a licensed travel agent, the Authority considers that the travel agent has ceased to carry on travel agent business.

subsection.leadIn: If the Authority intends to revoke or suspend a licensee’s licence in a summary way under subsection (1), it must, by notice in writing given to the licensee—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: notify the licensee of the intention; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: give reasons for the intention.

subsection.content: The licensee may, within 7 days after the date of the notice, or a longer period the Authority may permit, make representations in writing to the Authority as to why the licence should not be revoked or suspended.

subsection.leadIn: If the Authority decides to revoke or suspend the licensee’s licence, it must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: by notice in writing given to the licensee within 21 days beginning on the date on which the decision is made—

subparagraph.content: notify the licensee of the decision; and
give reasons for the decision; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: publish notice of the decision in any way the Authority considers appropriate.

subsection.leadIn: A decision made under subsection (4) takes effect on—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the date of the notice given under subsection (4)(a); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if a later date is specified in the notice, the later date.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (5) applies even if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an appeal has been lodged under section 120(1)(d) against the decision;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the period specified in section 120(2) has not expired; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a notice of the decision has not been published under subsection (4)(b).

section.name: s113
section.heading: Authority may shorten period of suspension or lift suspension

subsection.content: For a licence suspended under section 111 or 112, the Authority may, for good cause, whether on its own initiative or on application by the licensee concerned, shorten the period of suspension or lift the suspension.

subsection.leadIn: If the Authority decides to shorten the period of suspension of a licensee’s licence or lift the suspension, it must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: by notice in writing given to the licensee within 21 days beginning on the date on which the decision is made, notify the licensee of—

subparagraph.content: the decision; and
the period for which the period of suspension has been shortened, or the date on which the suspension is lifted; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: publish notice of the decision in any way the Authority considers appropriate.

subsection.leadIn: A decision made under subsection (1) takes effect on—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the date of the notice given under subsection (2)(a); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if a later date is specified in the notice, the later date.

subsection.content: Subsection (3) applies even if a notice of the decision has not been published under subsection (2)(b).

section.name: s114
section.heading: Effect of revocation or suspension of travel agent licence

subsection.content: This section applies to a person whose travel agent licence is revoked or suspended under this Part.

subsection.leadIn: The revocation or suspension of the person’s travel agent licence does not operate to avoid or affect any right, obligation or liability under any agreement, transaction or arrangement relating to the provision of a travel service—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that is entered into by the person at any time before the revocation or suspension; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in relation to which a sum of money has been paid at any time before the revocation or suspension.

subsection.leadIn: Despite section 61, when the person acts for the purpose of complying with the person’s obligation or liability under any agreement, transaction or arrangement mentioned in subsection (2) after the revocation or during the period of suspension, the person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is not to be regarded as contravening section 6(2) for carrying on travel agent business without licence; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must comply with the requirements of this Ordinance applicable to a licensed travel agent.

subsection.content: An inquiry committee established by the disciplinary committee, when conducting an inquiry under this Part, has the same privileges and immunities as it would have if the inquiry were a proceeding in a court.

A party, legal representative, witness or any other person who appears before an inquiry committee at an inquiry under this Part has the same privileges and immunities as the person would have if the inquiry were a proceeding in a court.
A legal adviser appointed under section 104(1)(f) may be present at any inquiry before an inquiry committee or deliberations of the committee to advise the committee.

subsection.leadIn: If the legal adviser advises the inquiry committee on any question of law as to evidence, procedure or any other matter in relation to an inquiry—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the legal adviser must do so in the presence of every party to the inquiry or person representing each party; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the advice is given after the committee has started to deliberate as to its decision, every party to the inquiry or person representing each party must be informed of the advice.

subsection.content: If the inquiry committee does not accept the advice of the legal adviser on a question, every party to the inquiry or person representing each party must be informed of that fact.
For hearing appeals under this Part, there is to be an appeal panel.
The Secretary must appoint at least 18 individuals as members of the panel.

subsection.leadIn: The Secretary must not appoint to the panel—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a public officer;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a member of the Authority or disciplinary committee; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a member of a committee or working group of the Authority.

subsection.content: The Secretary is to appoint one of the members of the panel as chairperson.

subsection.leadIn: In appointing the members of the panel, the Secretary must ensure that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the chairperson is a non-trade member; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: at least half of the other members are non-trade members.

subsection.content: Each member of the panel is to be appointed for a period of not more than 2 years, but is eligible for reappointment.

section.name: s118
section.heading: Resignation of members of appeal panel

subsection.content: A member of the appeal panel may, at any time, resign from office by giving written notice of the resignation to the Secretary.
The notice must be signed by the member.

subsection.leadIn: The notice takes effect on—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the date on which the notice is received by the Secretary; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if a later date is specified in the notice, the later date.

section.name: s119
section.heading: Removal of members of appeal panel from office

subsection.content: The Secretary may remove a member of the appeal panel from office if the Secretary considers that the removal is desirable for the panel to effectively perform its functions.
If a member of the appeal panel is removed from office, the Secretary must give the member written notice informing the member of the removal.

subsection.leadIn: A person aggrieved by any of the following matters may lodge an appeal against the matter—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a decision not to issue or renew a licence or business permit;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a decision to impose conditions on a licence or renewed licence;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a decision to amend or remove the conditions imposed on a licence;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a decision to revoke or suspend a licence or business permit;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: a decision or order to require an individual to cease to be an authorized representative of a licensed travel agent;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: a decision to refuse an application of a licensed travel agent made under section 28(6), 29, 30 or 109(5) for approval of an individual as the travel agent’s authorized representative;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: a decision to refuse to approve a licensed travel agent’s proposed change of the ownership or control of its business as a travel agent;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: an order made under section 98(2)(b) or 107(1) or (5) against a licensee;
an order made under section 106(1).

subsection.content: A person who wishes to appeal against a matter under subsection (1) must lodge a notice in writing with the Secretary within 28 days beginning on the date on which the notice of the matter is received, setting out the grounds of appeal.
The chairperson of the appeal panel may in a particular case extend the period specified in subsection (2) if the chairperson considers it appropriate to do so.
As soon as practicable after a notice of appeal has been lodged under section 120, the chairperson of the appeal panel must appoint from the panel an appeal board to hear the appeal.

subsection.leadIn: The appeal board is to consist of the following members—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a chairperson;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: at least 2 ordinary members.

subsection.leadIn: In appointing the members of the board, the chairperson of the panel must ensure that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the chairperson of the board and at least half of the ordinary members are non-trade members;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: at least one of the ordinary members is a trade member; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the members do not have a disclosable interest in the matter appealed against.

subsection.content: Subject to this Division and the regulations made under section 137, the procedure for convening a hearing of an appeal board and for the conduct of the hearing is to be decided by the board.
A hearing of an appeal board is to be presided over by the chairperson of the board.
The quorum for a hearing of an appeal board is 3 members of the board or one half of the members of the board, whichever is the greater.
For determining the quorum, if the number of members of the board is not an even number, the number is to be regarded as having been increased by 1.
A hearing of the board may be conducted only if a majority of the members present are non-trade members.
In the hearing of an appeal, every question before an appeal board is to be decided by a majority of votes of the members present and entitled to vote.
Subject to subsection (3), each member of the board who is present at the hearing has 1 vote.
If there is an equality of votes in respect of any question to be decided at the hearing, the chairperson of the board has a casting vote in addition to his or her original vote.

section.name: s125
section.heading: Parties to appeal
section.content: The parties to an appeal are the appellant and the Authority.

section.name: s126
section.heading: Date, time and place of hearing
section.leadIn: The chairperson of an appeal board must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: fix the date, time and place for the hearing of the appeal so that the hearing may commence as soon as practicable; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: serve on the parties to the appeal a notice of the date, time and place of the hearing.

subsection.leadIn: An appeal board has the following powers when hearing an appeal—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: power to take evidence on oath;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: power to summon a person to—

subparagraph.content: attend the hearing as a witness;
give evidence; and
provide any information or document in the person’s possession or under the person’s control that may be relevant to the hearing;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: power to examine witnesses;

paragraph.name: d
e
paragraph.content: power to determine the way in which any material mentioned in paragraph (d) is received;

paragraph.name: f
g
h
paragraph.content: power to make any order that may be necessary for or ancillary to the conduct of the hearing or the carrying out of its functions.

subsection.content: With the consent of the parties to the appeal, the board may hear an appeal on the basis of written submissions only.
If it appears to the board that the Authority or the disciplinary committee has reversed the matter appealed against, the board may determine the appeal in favour of the appellant.

subsection.leadIn: A party to the appeal—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may, subject to any order made by the board, be present at the hearing; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: may participate—

subparagraph.content: in person;
through a legal representative; or
with the consent of the board, through another person.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (4)(b)(i)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a company is to be regarded as participating in person if it participates through any of its directors; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a partnership is to be regarded as participating in person if it participates through any of its partners.

subsection.content: The board may make an order as to the payment of the costs and expenses incurred in relation to the hearing, whether by the board, any party to the appeal, or any person attending the hearing as a witness.

section.name: s128
section.heading: Summons
section.leadIn: A summons issued to a person under section 127(1)(b) must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: be in the specified form;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: be signed by the chairperson of the appeal board; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: specify the requirements that the person must comply with.

subsection.content: A person commits an offence if the person, without reasonable excuse, fails to comply with a summons issued to the person under section 127(1)(b).

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person, in connection with an appeal under section 127, gives any evidence, or provides any information or document, that is false or misleading in a material particular; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person knows that, or is reckless as to whether, the evidence, information or document is false or misleading in a material particular.

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under this section is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (2), the hearing of an appeal is to be held in public.
After consulting the parties to the appeal, an appeal board may, by order, direct that the hearing, or any part of the hearing, be held in private.
For the purposes of subsection (2), the board must have regard to the views or private interests of the parties to the appeal, including any claims as to privilege.

section.name: s131
section.heading: Prohibition on disclosure of appeal matters

subsection.leadIn: An appeal board may, by order, prohibit or restrict the publication or disclosure by all or any of the persons present at the hearing of an appeal of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any evidence given at the hearing; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any matter contained in any information or document provided or received in evidence at the hearing.

subsection.content: If a person fails to comply with an order made under subsection (1), the board may make an order against the person imposing a financial penalty not exceeding $5,000.

subsection.leadIn: If the board makes an order under subsection (2) against a person, it must, by notice in writing given to the person within 21 days beginning on the date on which the order is made—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: notify the person of the order; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: give reasons for the order.

subsection.leadIn: An order made under subsection (2) takes effect on—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the date of the notice given under subsection (3); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if a later date is specified in the notice, the later date.

subsection.content: The appellant may abandon the whole or any part of the appeal by notice in writing lodged with the chairperson of the appeal board.
The appellant must, as soon as practicable after the notice is lodged, serve a copy of the notice on the other parties to the appeal.

section.name: s133
section.heading: Failure of appellant to attend hearing

subsection.leadIn: If at the time fixed for the hearing of an appeal, the appellant fails to attend the hearing, whether in person or through a legal representative or some other person, an appeal board may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if it is satisfied that the appellant’s failure to attend the hearing was due to illness or another reasonable ground, postpone or adjourn the hearing for a period it considers appropriate; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: if it is satisfied that the appellant’s failure to attend the hearing was not due to illness or another reasonable ground—

subparagraph.content: proceed to hear the appeal; or
by order, dismiss the appeal.

subsection.leadIn: If an appeal is dismissed under subsection (1)(b)(ii)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the appellant may, within 28 days after the order for dismissal is made, apply to the board for a review of the order by notice in writing lodged with the chairperson of the board; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the board may, if it is satisfied that the appellant’s failure to attend the hearing was due to illness or another reasonable ground, set aside the order for dismissal.

subsection.content: A notice under subsection (2)(a) must be in the form specified by the chairperson of the appeal panel.
The appellant must, as soon as practicable after a notice is lodged under subsection (2)(a), serve a copy of the notice on the other parties to the appeal.

subsection.leadIn: If the board sets aside an order for dismissal under subsection (2)(b), the chairperson of the board must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: fix the date, time and place for a new hearing of the appeal so that the hearing may commence as soon as practicable; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: at least 14 days before the date so fixed serve on the parties to the appeal a notice of the date, time and place of the hearing.

subsection.content: An appeal board hearing an appeal may confirm, vary or reverse any decision or order to which the appeal relates.

The board must give reasons in writing for its decision, and those reasons must include its findings on material questions of fact and a summary of the evidence or other material on which those findings were based.
The board must serve a copy of its decision and of the reasons for its decision on the parties to the appeal.

subsection.leadIn: The board’s decision takes effect—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: subject to paragraph (b), immediately after the decision is made; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the board orders that its decision is not to come into operation until a specified date, on that date.

subsection.content: A document purporting to be a copy of a decision or order of the board and to be certified by the chairperson of the board to be a true copy of the decision or order is admissible in any proceedings as evidence of the decision or order.
The decision of the board is final.
An appeal board, when hearing an appeal under this Part, has the same privileges and immunities as it would have if the appeal were a proceeding in a court.

A party, legal representative, witness or any other person who appears before an appeal board at a hearing of an appeal under this Part has the same privileges and immunities as the person would have if the appeal were a proceeding in a court.
A legal adviser appointed under section 127(1)(f) may be present at any hearing before an appeal board or deliberations of the board to advise the board.

subsection.leadIn: If the legal adviser advises the board on any question of law as to evidence, procedure or any other matter in relation to a hearing—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the legal adviser must do so in the presence of every party to the appeal or person representing each party; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the advice is given after the board has started to deliberate as to its decision, every party to the appeal or person representing each party must be informed of the advice.

subsection.content: If the board does not accept the advice of the legal adviser on a question, every party to the appeal or person representing each party must be informed of that fact.

section.name: s137
section.heading: Regulations for Part 8
section.leadIn: The Secretary may make regulations for one or more of the following purposes—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to prescribe the procedures for the hearing of appeals under this Part;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to provide generally for the better carrying out of the purposes of this Part.

part.name: P9
part.heading: Travel Industry Compensation Fund and Levies

subsection.leadIn: In this Part—
subsection.def: outbound package (外遊服務組合) means a combination of 2 or more of the services and arrangements described in the following paragraphs relating to the same tour—(a)a service concerning carriage, by any means of transport, on a journey that is to commence in Hong Kong and then take place mainly outside Hong Kong;(b)a service concerning accommodation at a place outside Hong Kong;(c)arrangements for an activity—(i)that is not ancillary to a service mentioned in paragraph (a) or (b);(ii)that is to take place outside Hong Kong; and(iii)that, if included in the package, constitutes a substantial part of it;
outbound traveller (外遊旅客)—see subsection (2);
pre-existing fund (原有基金) means the fund established by section 32C of the repealed Ordinance as the Travel Industry Compensation Fund.

subsection.content: For the purposes of this Part, a person is an outbound traveller if the person has paid an outbound fare to a licensed travel agent, or an outbound fare has been paid for the person to a licensed travel agent, in connection with or in anticipation of the travel agent obtaining for the person an outbound travel service.
In this Part, a reference to a levy being payable or a requirement that a levy must be paid is to be construed as including the payment of the levy in advance.

To avoid doubt, for the purposes of this Part, if an outbound fare is paid to a person who, at the time the payment is made, is a licensed travel agent, the payment is not to be regarded as not having been made only because of a subsequent revocation or suspension of the licence of that travel agent.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: *commencement date (生效日期) means the commencement date of this section.

subsection.content: Despite the repeal of the repealed Ordinance, the pre-existing fund is to continue in existence in its original name “Travel Industry Compensation Fund”.

subsection.leadIn: The Compensation Fund consists of—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: money received on account of the Fund levy;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: income from any investment made under section 140; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: any other money paid into the Compensation Fund.

section.name: s140
section.heading: Powers of Authority in relation to Compensation Fund
section.leadIn: Without limiting the Authority’s general powers to hold, manage and apply the Compensation Fund, any money of the Compensation Fund that is not immediately required for the purposes of payments under sections 142 and 145 may be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: deposited on fixed term or call deposit or in a savings account in a bank nominated by the Financial Secretary, whether generally or in a particular case, for the purpose; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: invested in a way approved by the Financial Secretary.

section.name: s141
section.heading: Funds of Authority do not include Compensation Fund

subsection.content: To avoid doubt, the funds of the Authority do not include the Compensation Fund.

subsection.leadIn: The Authority must ensure that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a separate account is opened at a bank located in Hong Kong for the purpose of maintaining the Compensation Fund;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: all money in the Compensation Fund is credited to that account; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: all money so credited is kept in that account until applied in accordance with this Ordinance.

section.name: s142
section.heading: Ex gratia payments
section.content: The Authority may, on application, make ex gratia payments from the Compensation Fund to or in respect of outbound travellers in accordance with the regulations made under section 149.

subsection.leadIn: This section applies if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an outbound fare has been paid by or for an outbound traveller to a licensed travel agent; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Authority, in relation to a loss suffered by the outbound traveller in respect of the outbound fare, makes an ex gratia payment from the Compensation Fund to or in respect of the outbound traveller.

subsection.content: The Authority is subrogated, to the extent of the amount of the ex gratia payment, to all the rights and remedies of the outbound traveller by reason of the loss suffered by the outbound traveller.

The rights of the outbound traveller and the Authority in a bankruptcy or winding up or by legal proceedings or otherwise to receive, in respect of the loss, any sum out of the assets of the travel agent, are to rank equally.
All assets (whether in cash or otherwise) recovered by the Authority under this section become part of the Compensation Fund.

section.name: s144
section.heading: Offence relating to application for ex gratia payment

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person, in connection with an application for an ex gratia payment, makes any statement, or provides any information or document, that is false or misleading in a material particular; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person knows that, or is reckless as to whether, the statement, information or document is false or misleading in a material particular.

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under this section is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.leadIn: The Authority may also make from the Compensation Fund—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: payments regarding expenses incurred by the Authority in performing its functions in relation to the Compensation Fund, including—

subparagraph.content: payment of fees as regards the collection of the Fund levy; and
payment of auditors’ fees and expenses incurred in examining the economy, efficiency and effectiveness with which the Authority applies the Compensation Fund; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: payments for ex gratia payments that have been determined under the repealed Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: The Authority may—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: control the funds so set aside.

subsection.content: For the purposes of subsection (2), the Secretary may, by notice published in the Gazette, specify a percentage of the Compensation Fund as the maximum funds that the Authority may set aside to support the continuous development of the travel industry.
A licensed travel agent is liable to pay to the Authority, in respect of every outbound fare received by the travel agent, a levy (Authority levy).
The amount of the Authority levy is to be ascertained by reference to a specified percentage of the outbound fare.
The Secretary may, by notice published in the Gazette, specify the percentage.
The Authority levy must be paid to the Authority in the way and at the time decided by the Authority.
A licensed travel agent is liable to contribute to the Compensation Fund by way of levy (Fund levy) in respect of every outbound fare received by the travel agent.
The amount of the Fund levy is to be ascertained by reference to a specified percentage of the outbound fare.
The Secretary may, by notice published in the Gazette, specify the percentage.
The Fund levy must be paid to the Authority in the way and at the time decided by the Authority.

section.name: s148
section.heading: Electronic system
section.content: Payments of Authority levy and Fund levy, and the recording and proof of the payments, may be made through an electronic system prescribed by regulations made under section 149.

subsection.leadIn: The Authority may, after consulting the Secretary, make regulations for one or more of the following purposes—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: to prescribe the circumstances in which—

subparagraph.content: an application for an ex gratia payment may be made by or in respect of an outbound traveller; and
an ex gratia payment may be made to or in respect of an outbound traveller;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to prescribe the maximum amount or rate payable as an ex gratia payment to or in respect of an outbound traveller;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to prescribe the operation and details of a system for the collection, payment and recording of levies, including an electronic system.

subsection.content: Regulations made for the purposes of subsection (1)(c) may prescribe offences for contravention of the regulations, and may provide for the imposition in respect of such an offence of a fine not exceeding $200,000.

subsection.leadIn: The Authority may also make regulations for one or more of the following purposes—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to prescribe the way in which an application for an ex gratia payment is to be made;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to prescribe a period within which an application for an ex gratia payment is to be made;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: to enable the Authority—

subparagraph.content: to submit an application for an ex gratia payment as a proof of debt in any bankruptcy or winding up proceedings; and
to require the assignment of an outbound traveller’s rights of action as a pre-condition for the making of an ex gratia payment;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: to provide generally for the better carrying out of the purposes of this Part.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (3), the regulations may provide that—

paragraph.name: a
